Description: Fragment of rim of Tripolitanian pottery transport amphora. Clay near fine brick red; chocolate surface with cream wash. Rectangular stamp below rim with Latin inscription and symbol. Stamped on outside.
Curator's comments: Tripolitanian III olive oil amphora, also known as Ostia 64 and Peacock & Williams 36. Produced in Tripolitania, Libya, where several kiln sites are known (Panella, 1973; Arthur, 1982), including Zitha (Bonifay, 2004). They were produced to contain olive oil (Panella, 1973; Bonifay, 2004). Exported widely in the second to the first half of the third century AD. Stamp thought to be of Severan Date (early to mid 3rd century AD). Arthur, P. 1982. 'Amphora production in the Tripolitanian Gebel.' Libyan Studies, 61-72. Bonifay, M. 2004. Études sur la céramique romaine tardive d’Afrique. Oxford: Archaeopress , British Archaeological Reports. International Series. Keay, S & Williams, D. 2005. Roman Amphorae: a digital resource. University of Southampton. York: Archaeology Data Service. (doi:10.5284/1000021) Panella, C. 1973. 'Appunti su un gruppo di anfore della prima, media e tarda età Imperiale.' Ostia III: Le terme del Nuotatore: scavo dell'ambiente V et di un saggio dell'area. Studi miscellenei. 21: 460- 633 Panella, C. 1977. Anfore tripolitane a Pompei. L'instrumentum domesticum di Ercolano e Pompei nella prima età imperiale. 135-149 Peacock, D. P. S. & Williams, D. F. 1986 Amphorae and the Roman Economy. London: Longman
